We would like to help our friends at Dakota County as they work on assessing safety near schools – Your input is needed

Dakota County, in collaboration with MnDOT, is conducting a study to proactively address safety for students traveling to and from the 49 schools in Dakota County next to county roads and state highways. The study and recommendations will focus on pedestrian and bicyclist safety.

The county is currently hosting a virtual open house to share study goals and process and needs your feedback. You can share what works and what is challenging about walking and biking to school as well as bus and parent drop-off. The virtual open house materials are available now on the project website and will remain open until at least July 26. Visit the virtual open house now at: https://www.co.dakota.mn.us/Transportation/TransportationStudies/Current/Pages/school-safety-assessment.aspx

The Hastings School District has an opening for the non-public nurse position. The registered nurse in this role manages the health of students who attend the non-public schools (SEAS, St. John’s and The Harbor) and home-schooled students. You must have current Minnesota RN license. Approximately 30 hours/week - $32.86/hour. This is a non-contract position that does not include regular benefits. This job follows the school calendar…summers and holidays off! No nights or weekends! To apply, please visit our website www.hastings.k12.mn.us

The Hastings High School Horticulture Department is excited to announce despite COVID-19 we are still conducting our Annual Plant Sale. The format will be a little different this year, but there are still beautiful plants and hanging baskets available just in time for Mother’s day.

The sale will take place on Friday, May 8 from 10:00 AM – 4:00 PM and on Saturday, May 9th from 10:00 AM – 2:00 PM.

We will run the sale in the north parking lot enter the campus off of Featherstone Road to eliminate congestion on the west end of the school. There will be hay wagons for display. We will not be handling money or giving change so please plan accordingly. We also will have a box where people can individually put checks or cash. All shoppers are encouraged to wear masks and practice social distancing.

Pricing is as follows:
• All 12 inch hanging baskets $15.00
• 6 pack rectangular packs $ 2.00
• 4 inch individual plants $3.00

All the plants were grown by our students and the proceeds will go to benefit the Track and Nordic Ski Teams.

Spring Break 2020 wasn’t quite what we thought it would be, but it has brought us all together in a new way. Beginning on Monday, March 23, Hastings Public Schools will begin contributing to food security for students who are being forced to stay home due to the COVID-19 school closure

Here is our meal distribution plan:
The Hastings Bus Company will be delivering meals to bus stops on a 2 hour late start schedule. Any person who walks up the bus articulating that they are picking up a meal for a school-aged child will receive a bag containing 2 meals (one breakfast and one lunch).

Students who receive special transportation will be delivered directly to the door. Student who are walkers can pick-up food at one of our walk-up locations:

Elementary Walk-up:
McAuliffe & JFK
Buses will distribute meals in the parking lot near the main entrance from 10:00 – 10:30 AM

Pinecrest & Middle School Walk-up:
Middle School Main Entrance from 11:00 AM – 1:00 PM

High School Walk-up:
High School Student Entrance on the lower level from 11:00 AM – 1:00 PM

Back-to-School Tips to Help Your Student Thrive

Make time for PDF: playtime, downtime, family time. Research shows PDF is critical for overall well-being.

Create a technology-free environment during mealtimes. Every adult and child can benefit from a break from constant interruptions and distractions.

Collaborate with your child’s teachers. Assume best intentions and work together to solve problems.

An extra hour of sleep is more valuable than an extra hour of studying. Research shows sleep deprivation can be associated with depression and anxiety.

Help your child develop his or her interests and strengths. Discover what your child really loves to do outside of school, not what you think a college admissions officer would like to see on an application.

Collaborate with your child’s teachers. Assume best intentions and work together to solve problems.

An extra hour of sleep is more valuable than an extra hour of studying. Research shows sleep deprivation can be associated with depression and anxiety.

Help your child develop his or her interests and strengths. Discover what your child really loves to do outside of school, not what you think a college admissions officer would like to see on an application.

The ACT is cancelled tomorrow, Saturday April 14th, due to the winter storm warning. This is a change.

When a test site is cancelled due to weather, the first thing we do is notify ACT. ACT then gets back to us next week with our options.

One option will be to have a “rescheduled test date” that is not one of predetermined national test dates. For example, they may tell us we can test next Saturday or the following Saturday. These are not standard test dates, but “rescheduled test dates” specific to our testing site. ACT will notify students of the rescheduled test date.

The other option will be for students to opt to take the test on another national test date. For example, they may not be able to make the rescheduled test date, but they can test on the next national test date (i.e. June 9th, 2018).

At this time, the only thing students need to do is wait until they hear directly from ACT in the next few days. Check the email you used when you registered for updated information.
